text: Hey, has anyone made Glide to play gif only on click? Or somehow optimise gif memory usage? I'm writing small gallery like app which would load pictures from various imgur source, and some pictures can be gifs. At first tested on powerful (4 cores, 2gb ram) emulator and it goes smoothly with loading 100+ gifs in recyclerview. But then I tried on shitty version emulator (1 core, 512 mb ram. And while it loads full screen of gifs, their framerate is terrible, So i thought perhaps I could do the thing other sites are doing - play gif only on click/long click, whatever. Or perhaps don't play it in the list, show some overlay that notifies it's a gif and only onclick maximize it to fullscreen and then play it?
Oh damn, this post is longer than I expected :smile:
I think I semi-solved it by changing cache strategy to                 .diskCacheStrategy(DiskCacheStrategy.ALL)
Will try to increase thread count as well probably
is there any reason why travis would fail on linting while my local build doesn’t?
running exactly the same commands
just default lint? how does it fail?

```

-----------
```

will run with info and debug flags
its just annoying af
because the fucking travis doesn’t show you the output.
weird
ok I know what to do
I’ll have the next command cat the lint log :joy:
sounds fun :stuck_out_tongue:
I just hope it doesn’t terminate before that.
it still makes no sense how it would use a different config unless you explicitly told it to
fuck do I know mate
ok that worked

```
NewApi: Calling new methods on older versions
../../../AndroidNorthLib: The SDK platform-tools version (23.0.1) is too old to check APIs compiled with API 24; please update
Note: This issue has an associated quickfix operation in Android Studio/IntelliJ & Eclipse/ADT Fix 
Priority: 6 / 10
Category: Correctness
Severity: Error
Explanation: Calling new methods on older versions.
This check scans through all the Android API calls in the application and warns about any calls that are not available on all versions targeted by this application (according to its minimum SDK attribute in the manifest).

If you really want to use this API and don't need to support older devices just set the minSdkVersion in your build.gradle or AndroidManifest.xml files.

If your code is deliberately accessing newer APIs, and you have ensured (e.g. with conditional execution) that this code will only ever be called on a supported platform, then you can annotate your class or method with the @TargetApi annotation specifying the local minimum SDK to apply, such as @TargetApi(11), such that this check considers 11 rather than your manifest file's minimum SDK as the required API level.

If you are deliberately setting android: attributes in style definitions, make sure you place this in a values-vNN folder in order to avoid running into runtime conflicts on certain devices where manufacturers have added custom attributes whose ids conflict with the new ones on later platforms.

Similarly, you can use tools:targetApi="11" in an XML file to indicate that the element will only be inflated in an adequate context.

More info:

To suppress this error, use the issue id "NewApi" as explained in the Suppressing Warnings and Errors section.
Disabled Checks

```
This should have definitelly popped up in your local build
did the support lib version change somehow in the ci?
or maybe the target api
nope.
only other reason is if travis somehow uses platform tools 23
:s
that's what is probably happening
<https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/6193>

attachments.title: Android: missing latest platform-tools 24 · Issue #6193 · travis-ci/travis-ci · GitHub
attachments.text: Android SDK has been updated with latest platform tools version 24. When running locally I was able to find them and install, but when running in Travis, platform-tools always points to 23.0.1. Com...
attachments.fallback: GitHub: Android: missing latest platform-tools 24 · Issue #6193 · travis-ci/travis-ci

text:
You might need something like this in the yaml file
```
android:
    components:
        - platform-tools
        - tools
        - build-tools-23.0.3
        - android-24
```
I can’t have build-tools-23.0.3
ok it's more complicated than that then
apparently you need tools twice
fml
:smile:
we had travis disabled for a while on the epic we’re working on as it’s a major breaking rewrite
decided to enable it yesterday
and now it’s all gone to hell
this is why you always need CI/CD, kids.
leaving a tool out of the toolchain for a bit will always bring pain later
:smile:
yep
fml
another day where I spend some 6 hours looking at the build progress and fiddling my thumbs.

This might be a difficult question to answer, but I have a Viewpager with 4 fragments. Whenever the fragment in position 2 enters the screen fully, I fire off a postrequest, fetching updated data and put it into pojos and perform changes via a recyclerview adapter.
The adapter handles 0 total items by displaying a row saying "no items", and for debug reasons handle the injected pojo list being null as a row with “something went wrong, press here to refresh” (this has never been needed/displayed in production though).

 99/100 times this does exactly as expected, but every now and then, the adapter does not get assigned to the recyclerview. No caught/uncaught exceptions, no warnings. recyclerview is not null when this happens, I got no idea what is going on, and this seems very broad, but have anyone ever ran into something similar and know what is going on?
same device, or different devices?
both
could it be that 2 instances of the recyclerview exist at any given time?
log their hashcodes
<@U0H67LJUA> how do you handle config changes?

Changing the adapter? I used to handle it internally in the adapter (notifyItemschanged) after getting a different dataset. But in the process of getting to the root of this, i create a new adapter every time. Both approaches have the same result.
Quick question - who should handle Recycler view item click? ViewHolder? Adapter in onBind? or?..
Or kind of both? Just found an answer that ViewHolder should catch onClick event and pass it through static interface that adapter will override in onBind? That seems reasonable

Thats odd, managed to get the bug to happen, hash value of recyclerview is 91107(..), destroy the fragment, fragment is recreated, recyclerview hash is still 91107(,,), normally it changes. The recycler is not used outside of this class, I don’t pass it anywhere or otherwise keep it around when destroyed.

I’m seeing something very weird while doing something very easy

```
        Observable.timer(200, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
                .take(15)
                .count()
                .subscribeOn(<http://Schedulers.io|Schedulers.io>())
                .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
                .subscribe({ int -> Timber.e("Count $int") },
                        { error -> Timber.e(error.message) },
                        { Timber.e("I am complete") })
```
Am I missing something? After 1 emit I receive onComplete
I think you need a flatmap so that count doesn’t complete the stream
Oh shit lol count is closing my stream ><
Sec lemme try that
Hmm nope, same problem without count
take doesn’t play well with timer it seems :disappointed:
I just need a list of x items, with y delay between every item.
But when I used flatmap -> delay I never received onComplete
oh I dont think timer is what you want
did you mean to use repeat?
>The Timer operator creates an Observable that emits one particular item after a span of time that you specify.
I think you want Interval
>The Interval operator returns an Observable that emits an infinite sequence of ascending integers, with a constant interval of time of your choosing between emissions.
sorry yes interval not repeat
<@U0548MM6B> :taco:
yes
lol interval instead of timer! haha
